iati-activity.title: UNDP-JOINT HIV/AIDS PROGRAMME
iati-activity.description: This is support to Joint UN Programme on AIDS in Uganda to targeted communities
iati-activity.participating-org: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Availability of information on HIV and AIDS spending. - Level of mainstreaming of HIV and gender issues in development policies, programmes and plans - Existence of adequate capacity of umbrella organisations to coordinate HIV responses. - Existence of human resources in the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Existence of evidence to inform sustainable financing mechanisms / options for the HIV response

baseline.comment: - No information on actual spending on HIV and AIDS - Limited mainstreaming of HIV and gender issues in development policies, programmes and plans - Inadequate capacity of umbrella organisations to coordinate HIV responses. - Inadequate capacity of the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Unsustainable financing mechanisms for the HIV response

target.comment: -Information on HIV and AIDS spending availed e.g National AIDS accountability Score card institutionalized - HIV and gender issues mainstreamed in development policies, programmes and plans. Specfically: 1. An HIV committee established in Kampala city authority 2- Increased number of top political and urban leaders committed to the National HIV response 3- Non communicable disease health clubs established among university students 4- Increase in the number of newspaper publications on Non communicable diseases and tobacco control 5- At least 15 women and girls living with and orphaned with HIV supported in 2 districts to regain access to property and land 6- Advocacy for removal of clauses that impact on HIV regression in the HIV Prevention and Management bill 7- Advocacy with law makers and policy makers on the need to manage the impact of the Anti homosexuality Act - Adequate capacity of umbrella organisations in place to coordinate HIV responses. e.g Supporting Uganda AIDS Commission to engender the National HIV Strategic Plan and the Global fund process -Availability of Human resources in the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Evidence in place to inform sustainable financing mechanisms / options for the HIV response

actual.comment:
-Availability of information on HIV and AIDS spending. National Aids accountability score card was launched, disseminated and institutionalized in 7 districts, as a result there is increased accountability of health services in certain health centers like Mwiizi health center 4 where the government vehicle was brought back due to the community demand . -HIV and gender issues have been to some extent mainstreamed in development policies, programmes and plans. Specifically: 1- An HIV committee was institutionalized at Kampala City authority which has facilitated the organization of the elimination of mother to child transmission campaign in Kampala district 2- Increased commitment of political leaders in addressing the HIV response which has contributed to decline in the number of new infections from 140,000 to 120,000 and also lead to the reduction mother to child transmission rates from 21000 to 8000 new infections ( Country Progress report) 3- Urban leaders currently integrating gender and HIV in their urban programs and plans as a result there is increased commitment of urban leaders in mobilizing their communities to access HIV prevention, care and treatment services 4 - Two non communicable disease health clubs have been established in Mukono and Kampala University 5 - One way SMS platform has been develop to sensitize the youth about the dangers of smoking and related non communicable diseases. 6- Eleven women and 7 girls living with and affected with HIV have been supported to regain access to their property and land , as a result 2 girls that had dropped out school have bounced back to school.
7- As a result of the gender and HIV integration study conducted last year, gender and HIV training have been conducted for the local government sectors leading to the increase in gender informed budgets and work plans submitted to the ministry of local government; 8.An HIV and the law dialogue was conducted in an effort to sensitize policy makers,

target.comment: i. Conduct 1 Urban Leaders AIDS Forum ii.Review 3 AMICAAL policies iii.240 students sensitized and capacities built to do peer education on HIV and NCDs prevention iv. 1 documentary for TV mentions for 2 months about health service delivery from rural health centres v.Provide legal aid to 60 clients

document-link.title: JUPSA Annual Narrative Progress Report final

location.name: Mbale

iati-activity.title: Low Emission Capacity Building project
iati-activity.description: This is a low emission capacity building project. (LECB)

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Thematic working group on GHG inventory system and national dialogue platforms and coordination mechanisms established. 2. Number of Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMA) full proposals in place. 3. MRV for GHG inventory systems and NAMAs in place.

baseline.comment: 1. There are no thematic working groups and dialogue platforms on GHG inventory systems in place. 2. There is no systematic Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs) development full proposal yet. 3. There is no MRV for GHG Inventory system and NAMA in place.

target.comment: 1. Thematic Working Group on GHG Inventory established and Sources of available data in key source categories identified. 2. Two NAMA full proposals prepared. 3. MRV systems designed to support implementation and evaluation of NAMAs.

actual.comment: 1. Thematic working groups on Greenhouse Gas inventory created and capacity developed. A study was also completed on institutional and data collecting arrangements that identified the available data in the key sectors. Furthermore was a Greenhouse Gas Manual developed to guide the UNDP facilitated Greenhouse Gas Unit under the Climate Change department to support the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory system. 2. Formulation of 2 NAMA development processes is on track. One NAMA concept has received funds from GEF to be fully implemented and another NAMA concept will be developed to a full proposal funded by the LECB global unit. 3. Design of MRV systems is on track. The MRV workshop in June was very fruitful and is a very good starting point for establishing MRV system for the NAMAs. The training was followed by two more training sessions in November and December where stakeholders came with input to the MRV framework .

target.comment: -A long term green house gas (GHG) inventory strategy in place -An institutionalized data collection system in place spearheaded by the GHG inventory unit -A sustainable and institutionalized QA/QC system in place -Capacities built within government for GHG inventory management -GHG inventory adopted and institutionalized for periodic inventorying and NCs - Rules of procedure detailed as part of a GHG inventory and NCs manual (timelines, budget -Business models develop for at least four NAMAs

document-link.title: 00061683_Approved 2011 AWP EU UNDP CC CP Project for Uganda

iati-activity.title: Low Emission Capacity Building
iati-activity.description: This project is a low emission capacity building project focuses on strengthening Ugandas technical and institutional capacity in the development of Green House Gas inventory systems and Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions.

iati-activity.title: Pilot Initiatives projects-Environment
iati-activity.description: Strengthening Sustainable Environment and Natural Resource Management, Climate Change Adaptation and Mitigation in Uganda

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Demonstration nurseries for trial and propagation of selected threatened tree species in place. 2. Acreage of degraded sites planted with threatened tree species 3. Number of target communities supported to develop eco-tourism strategies. 4. Number of community based organizations identified to pilot sustainable land management best practices. 5. Acreage of fragile environments/ dry lands planted with recommended trees. 6. Number institutional and household biogas units constructed. 7. Quantity of Renewable Energy Technologies (RET) produced/ adopted. 8. Number of innovative Climate change adaptation initiatives established

baseline.comment: 1. Zero or No demonstration nurseries for threatened tree species in biodiversity hot spots. 2. Fragile environments are degraded and bare. 3. No target communities supported to develop eco-tourism strategies. Some areas have eco-tourism potential but lack innovative products for ecotourism. 4. Communities not implementing SLM best practices. 5. Fragile and dry lands are bare with no recommended trees. 6. Low adoption of alternative energy technologies such as no institutional and household biogas units. 7. There are no and/or inadequate quantities of RET produced/ adopted within the target communities. 8. Zero or no innovative climate change adaptation initiatives in target communities.

target.comment: 1. Demonstration nurseries for at least four (4) species of conservation concern in place 2. 1000ha in both institutions and degraded sites planted with both tree species of conservation concern and non-conservation concern 3. At least three (3) community management strategies and plans for ecotourism management in place 4. At least three (3) community based Catchment management action plans implementing SLM interventions. 5. 1000ha of degraded fragile landscapes restored through planting of recommended trees 6. At least 6 biogas units constructed. 7. At least three efficient biomass energy technologies tested and four community groups plus two institutions using RET 8. Sub-surface rain water harvesting technologies exist in 4 target districts

actual.comment: 1. Two demonstration nurseries for trial and propagation of selected threatened tree species established including one in Kasese District and another in Mitooma Districts. 2. A total of 148 Ha of degraded sites planted with threatened tree species. These included a total of 75 Ha of degraded sites in Kasese namely Mobuku forest reserve, Bugoye and Kitholu sub counties where a total of 35,000 seedlings were planted, and a total of 50 Ha in Mitooma District including 42 Ha where 19000 seedlings were planted on the bare hills of Katenge, Kabira Primary School and Bubare Church of Uganda and the 8 Ha in Kiryabwanga sub country where about 8000 seedlings were planted. 3. Two Community Based Organizations supported under the Small Grants Scheme to promote eco-tourism initiatives including one to construct a viewing platform at the escarpment and another to make paper from elephant dung both in Rubirizi Districts near Queen Elizabeth National Park. 4. Nineteen Community Based Organizations identified under the Small Grants Scheme were practicing sustainable land management best practices through tree planting, digging of trenches across the steep slopes in Districts of Kasese, Mitooma, Rubirizi, Bududa and Manafwa Districts. For instance, in Bududa District along the slopes of Mountain Elgon, 39.5 km of trenches have been constructed and use of mulch & cow dung manure adopted. 5. One hundred and twenty four Hectares of fragile and dry lands planted with recommended trees including 105 Ha with indigenous species and 19 Ha with exotic species. 6. Two institutional biogas units were constructed including one in Butiru Secondary School in Manafwa District and one in Karambi Secondary School in Kasese District. 10 household biogas units were constructed including 4 in Manafwa, 2 in Isingiro Districts and another 4 household biogas units in Bududa. 7. One hundred and eighty mud cook stoves were constructed and distributed by a total of 11 Community Based Organizations. 8. S

target.comment: 1. 1000ha in both institutions and degraded sites planted with both tree species of conservation concern and non conservation concern as well as 1000ha of degraded landscapes restored. 2. At least six efficient biomass energy technologies tested in four Districts plus one institutions using Renewable Energy Technologies (RET). 3. At least three (3) community groups promoting climate resilient development strategies.

actual.comment:
1. A total of 584.6 Ha were planted with trees and stabilized with vegetation cover under small grants.
A total of 405.6ha were planted under small grants [in Kasese district, 124ha in Kitholhu Sub-County, 55.8ha in Mobuku forest reserve plus 7ha on private land; and in Mitooma district, bare hills of Katenga (0.8ha), Kabira (2ha), Kiyanga (1ha), Kashenshero (3ha) and Kanyabwanga (0.5ha) plus Mitooma town council (1ha)]. On the other hand, establishment of demonstration apiaries in the districts of Kasese (1) and Rubirizi (1) was supported. In addition, two CFM groups in the districts of Kasese and Rubirizi, that is, MIFA and BUECA respectively were trained on modern Beekeeping.
In addition a total of 179ha of fragile ecosystems were stabilized with vegetation cover under small grants throughout the districts of Bududa, Rubirizi, Mitooma and Kasese districts. In addition, a total of 88.5km of trench and water bands were constructed and vegetation cover to stabilize them planted (Bududa district 60.5km, Mitooma district 2km and Kasese district 26km). 2. A total of 17 Renewable Energy Technologies were established including 2 institutional biogas facilities constructed in the schools of Karambi and Butiru in Kasese and Manafwa districts respectively and 15 domestic biogas units including eight (8) in Manafwa district by a CBO, Youth ending hunger; six (6) in Bududa district by Namasho women group; one (1) in Isingiro district by Conservation Effort for Community Development (CECOD) were constructed. In addition, six (6) domestic biogas units were constructed through two contractors four in Manafwa district by NABUTI Renewable Energy Construction Company (2 units) and Mbale Renewable Energy (2 units) and, two (2) in Isingiro district by Ankole private sector foundation.
3. More than eight (8) communities were supported to promote climate development strategies ranging from sub surface water harvesting technologies, water harvesting tanks, planting of coffee seedli

iati-activity.title: CAPACITY FOR AID EFFECTIVENESS
iati-activity.description: Enhancing the capacity of Aid Liaison Department (ALD), Implementing Partners and UNDP to be better placed to deliver respectively: Effective and efficient aid coordination, CPAP Outcomes and Project Quality Assurance.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: i) Number of staff trained in aid coordination, project management and quality assurance ii) Functional Monitoring mechanism for aid coordination and management in place iii) Number of donor funded project monitoring reports iv) CPAP midterm/annual review reports

baseline.comment: 1. No /Insufficient staff skills for Aid Coordination, Result based project implementation and Quality Assurance Inadequate knowledge of best practices to coordinate aid 2. No functional Monitoring mechanism for aid coordination and management in place. Poor reporting and accountability due to weak monitoring and Evaluation systems in place. Inadequate and malfunctioning equipment in place. 3. No Monitoring reports; 4. No programme reviews/evaluations

target.comment: 1.20 staff trained in aid coordination, project management and quality assurance. Build skills of Aid Liaison Department (ALD) staff in Overseas Development Aid (ODA) management through training basing on the Training Needs assessment report. 2. Functional Monitoring mechanism for aid coordination and management in place.Development partner data reconciled for annual ODA reporting 3. Project reports ( audit; annual/portfolio review) in place and action Plan in place. At least 5 international and 3 local events on ODA best practices supported and at least one best practice applied for ODA management 4. UNDAF Review conducted, recommendations shared. Annual CPAP evaluation conducted, recommendations shared

Output 1: Current knowledge and best practices on ODA coordination attained and applied
1. 20 staff trained in ODA management related courses; At least 4 international and 3 local ODA events supported and one best practice implemented 2. Development partner data reconciled for annual ODA reporting
3.Report on impact of Aid finalized and disseminated
Output 2: CO Programme oversight and management successfully undertaken in line with UNDPs policies and procedures. 1. UNDAF Review report in place and recommendations 2. Country Programme Document 2015-2020 approved by government 3. New projects micro-assessed and IPs trained in UNDP policies and procedures. 4. 2015 UNDAF Review conducted;

actual.comment:
Existence of a functional monitoring and evaluation mechanism for Aid coordination and management.
The UNDP country office took deliberate strides to enhance its contribution to gender empowerment and equality outcomes by participating in the corporate gender seal process.
The UNDP country office has also formulated the 2016-2020 CPD and is yet to be approved by the Executive Board in September 2015. This new country programme comprise two significantly related portfolios: inclusive, effective governance and sustainable, inclusive economic development.

iati-activity.title: Strengthening Ug. Disaster Preparedness & Mgt Cap
iati-activity.description: Project on Strengthening Ugandas Disaster Preparedness and Management Capacities

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Number of institutions integrating environment, Climate Change, DRR and energy access in development plans; (Disaggregated by level i.e National/Local government

baseline.comment: No and/or Ineffectual institutional capacity for selected national institutions and Local Governments to review, develop and implement policies/strategies for ENRM/CC adaptation, mitigation and DRR in place (2010

target.comment: -20 institutions integrate environment, Climate Change, DRR and energy access in development plans; -Established institutions and processes for early warning, disaster and climate modelling, assessments and emergency/recovery coordination. - Conduct nationwide comprehensive hazard, risk, and Vulnerability mapping/profiling - Pilot of innovative approaches on Disaster and climate risk and resilience-building - Improved preparedness level and response to early recovery needs. - Improved capacities and harmonized tools/approaches for more efficient delivery of Disaster /Climate Risk Management initiatives - capacity at national and sub national levels in place to manage disaster and climate risk management

actual.comment: - 25 institutions integrated environment, Climate Change, DRR and energy access in development plans -Existence of established and operationalized institutions and process for early warning, disaster and climate modelling, assessments and emergency/recovery coordination. - Nationwide comprehensive hazard, risk, and Vulnerability mapping/profiling completed - Innovative approaches on Disaster and climate risk and resilience-building piloted - Existence of an institution for Improved preparedness level and response to early recovery needs. - Harmonized tools/approaches in place for more efficient delivery of Disaster /Climate Risk Management initiatives - Capacity at national and sub national levels to manage disaster and climate risk management in place

target.comment: - Develop the Strategic Programmes and Investment Framework document - Strengthen co-ordination of DRR activities through the conduct and facilitation of regular National Platform for DRR meetings. -Operationalize and roll out the Early Warning systems in targeted districts in Teso, Acholi and West Nile sub regions. - Conduct national Hazard Risk and Vulnerability assessment for targeted districts and publish their hazard profiles. - Commemorate the observance of special days/events including the International day for DRR.

actual.comment: i) Strengthened national DRR institutions, enhanced sectoral coordination and DRR main-streamed into national and sector-specific development policies and programmes ii. Evidence base for DRR generated and post-disaster recovery strengthened iii. Enhanced community resilience to disasters iv. Enhanced capacity for comprehensive disaster risk reduction

iati-activity.title: National Development Plan (2015-2020)
iati-activity.description: Support the Development of the National Development Plan 2015-2020

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Existence of a new macroeconomic framework for National Development Plan (NDP-II) 2. Number of selected NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced i.e.
3. Existence of Spatial mapping report and associated maps 4. Existence of NDPII incorrporating an M&E framework.

baseline.comment:
1. No new macroeconomic framework for National Development Plan (NDP-II) . Only NDPI exists; 2. No NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced yet.
3. No existence of Spatial mapping report and associated maps 4. None existence of NDPII incorporating an M&E framework.

target.comment:
1. A new macroeconomic framework for National Development Plan (NDP-II) in place 2. Five selected NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced
3. Spatial mapping report and associated maps in place 4. Existence of NDPII incorporating an M&E framework.

actual.comment:
1. A New macroeconomic framework for NDP-II was developed 2. Six selected NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced i.e. a. NDP-II cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of Democratic governance and the NDP-II completed b. NDP-II cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of Sustainability, environmental management and the NDP-II completed c. NDP-II Cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of Mainstreaming Non-State Actors participation in the NDP completed d. NDP-II Cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of youth in the NDP completed e. NDP-II Cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of agriculture and land main streaming in the NDP completed f. NDP-II LG Issues papers completed. 4. Spatial mapping report and associated maps completed 5. NDPII completed incorporating an M&E framework
1.1 Macro framework draft has been finalized and will be presented to cabinet and Parliament for review and approval. 1.2 The Core macro team from NPA was trained in development strategies through Sustainable Development Modeling (SDM). The SDM integrates two models that is the Marquette for MDGs Simulations model that was used in the preparation of the Uganda MDG report 2013 and the Osymoses model that analyses energy efficiency, as well as other enabling factors such as land, agriculture and the environment which will come in handy given the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals.

target.comment: 1. Provide technical Backstopping of Local Gorvenments and Municipalities in developing their development plans 2. Ensure Quality Assurance of Local Government Development Plans 3. Provide Project management support

actual.comment: National Planning Authority has so far trained over 30 Local Governments on the use of the LG development planning guidelines and supported them in developing their plans. This activity is expected to end in the last week of June. NPA will start providing Quality Assurance in July 2015.

iati-activity.title: Enhancing Adoption of Climate Smart Agriculturein Uganda
iati-activity.description: This project will focus on enhancing productivity of land through sustainable land management of soil and water resources, particularly integrating CSA as a climate change adaptation strategy to build climate change resilient societies.
iati-activity.participating-org: Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1 Number of hectares of land under CSA practices in the 5 districts 2 Number of schools in the 5 district integrate CSA in their gardens 3 Number of private sector input actors participate in the supply of quality inputs on market. 4 Number of input credit system established per district 5 Number of artisans trained in production of CSA tools 6 Number of producer associations identified, trained and supported to establish SACCOs 7 Lessons on CSA documented 8 Number of CSA technologies for which trials are carried out 9 Number of publication of findings and recommendations

baseline.comment: 1. 2,500 hectares of land under Climate Smart Agriculture practices in target districts 2 No school in the 5 districts integrate CSA 3 1 private sector input actor (Uganda National Agro Inputs Dealers Association) participate in supply of quality inputs on market 4 No input credit system established per district 5 1 artisan (TONNET Enterprise Limited) trained in production of CSA tools 6 No Producer Associations identified, trained and supported to establish Savings and Credit Cooperative Associations. 7 No lessons on CSA documented and disseminated. Limited knowledge management, no clear mechanism for generating and sharing lessons. 8 No trials for CSA technologies carried out 9 No publication of findings and recommendations

target.comment: 1 At least 15,000 hectares put under CSA practices in 5 districts. 2 At least 20 schools in the 5 districts integrate CSA in their gardens. 3 At least 15 private sector actors participate in the supply of quality inputs on market. 4 At least one input credit system established per district. 5 At least 10 artisans trained in production of CSA tools. 6 At least 10 producer associations identified, trained and supported to establish Savings and Credit Cooperative Organisations (SACCOs). 7 Lessons on CSA documented and available for dissemination. 8 Trials on at least four (4) CSA technologies carried out. 9 At least 2 publications of findings and recommendations.

actual.comment: 1 14 hectares (1 Ha per school for 14 schools) put under CSA practices in 5 districts 2 14 schools in the 5 districts trained to integrate CSA in their gardens. 3 1 private sector actors participate in the supply of quality inputs on market. 4 No input credit system established per district 5 No artisans trained in production of CSA tools. 6 No producer associations identified, trained and supported to establish Savings and Credit Cooperative Organisations (SACCOs) 7 No lessons on CSA documented and available for dissemination 8 No trials on any CSA technologies carried out 9 No publications of findings and recommendations

target.comment: 1. At least 10,000 hectares put under CSA practices in 5 districts 2. At least 30 schools in the 5 districts integrate CSA in their gardens. 3. 3,500 farmers practice CSA in the five targeted districts of Bugiri, Busia, Budaka, Namutumba and Buyende. 4. Capacity of Stakeholders in Particular Extension Staff, Farmer - Trainers Of Trainers and School Teachers Developed to Extend CSA Technologies. 5. Mechanization of Conservation agriculture practices done with 200 sets of rippers methodology developed to monitor impact of CSA practices among farmers in the 5 districts 6. At least 15 private sector actors participate in the supply of quality inputs on market. 7. At least 10 artisans trained in production of CSA tools. 8. At least 10 producer associations identified and trained and supported to establish Savings and Credit Cooperative Organisations (SACCOs) 9. Capacity of members of at least 10 producer associations built to do effective post harvest handling of crop

actual.comment: 1. 500 ha was put under CSA practices in the 5 districts 2. 30 schools integrated CSA in their school gardens, particularly conservation agriculture including use of permanent planting basins and mulching for minimum tillage, soil and water conservation structures, early planting and use of improved quality seeds. This activity included 250 girls, 350 boys in the 5 districts. 3. A total of 2500 farmers including 1378 women, 561 men in the five districts practiced CSA using maize and beans as major crops produced. 4. At least 320 farmers and farmer trainers were trained including 115 females. 5. 2 sets of rippers were used to demonstrate the use of rippers instead of ploughs, in a bid to mechanise conservation agriculture practice of minimum tillage. 6. Activity still on-going. 7. At least 5 private sector actors including NASECo seed company. 8. Activity still on-going. 9. Activity not yet started.
